article.description: North Carolina relied on an unusual weapon to end its skid against North Carolina State -- defense.
article.headline: Tar Heels settled for jumpers vs. strong defense
article.linkText: Tar Heels snap losing streak to rival NC State
article.story: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. (AP) -- No one had to tell Sean May or his North Carolina teammates that the Tar Heels hadn't beaten North Carolina State in almost three years. But the players made sure to remind each other once more Wednesday night. "That's the first thing we said before we walked on the floor," May said, "'We're not going to let them come in here and get a win." Raymond Felton scored 14 points and Rashad McCants added 13 to lift the Tar Heels (No. 15 ESPN/USA Today, No. 12 AP) past the Wolfpack 68-66, earning their first win in the series since February 2001. May had 11 points and 10 rebounds for North Carolina (13-4, 3-3 Atlantic Coast Conference), which had lost four straight to North Carolina State (11-5, 4-2). North Carolina had trouble defending North Caroline State's patient offense in the first half, giving up several scores inside on cuts to the basket or crisp passing. But the Tar Heels used an aggressive trapping defense to pick up the pace of the second half, forcing 13 turnovers and converting several to transition scores. The Tar Heels got better pressure on the ball, making it harder for the Wolfpack to make the precise passes of the first half. North Carolina held State without a point for more than six minutes during a 21-5 run that gave the Tar Heels a 10-point lead. North Carolina then held off a late rally to end its skid against N.C. State. "It was attitude and effort," said David Noel, who scored eight points. "We had to pick up our effort and change our attitude about how we were going to play defense, and that is what we did." The Tar Heels helped themselves by taking the ball to the basket in the second half, going 13-for-15 from the line after settling for plenty of jumpers against the Wolfpack's active first-half defense. They also controlled the glass, taking a 32-25 rebounding advantage. That included a 12-5 edge on the offensive boards against a team that pulled down 21 offensive rebounds in Saturday's win against Georgia Tech. "It wasn't an adjustment (at halftime)," Felton said. "It was just basically coming out with better intensity, deciding to guard people and deciding to be scrappy on defense." Marcus Melvin scored 15 points for the Wolfpack, who swept the series the past two seasons, and Julius Hodge added 12. Trailing 42-36, the Tar Heels finally got their offense going, thanks partly to their defense and taking the ball inside. They got a layup from Noel and a dunk from Felton -- both off turnovers -- and a turnaround shot in the block from McCants. They also went 6-for-6 at the line by going to the hoop over the next six minutes, taking a 51-47 lead. The Wolfpack offense, which operated with ease in the first half, managed just a putback from Melvin and a 3-pointer from Levi Watkins during that run. State, which shot 58 percent in the first half, had just three field goals in the first 12½ minutes of the second half. "I thought we battled like crazy and needed to make some more plays to win the game," State coach Herb Sendek said. "They have a lot of quickness and they really get out and extend passing lanes." Noel's jumper gave the Tar Heels their biggest lead at 57-47 with 8:17 to play. N.C. State made a late run, getting two 3-pointers in the final 65 seconds from Engin Atsur to cut the deficit to 68-66 with 1.3 seconds left. But McCants caught the inbounds pass and ran out the clock. "We weren't having very good luck at stopping them at almost anything (in the first half)," North Carolina coach Roy Williams said. The trap "slowed them down. They didn't feel very comfortable attacking it." N.C. State finished with 20 turnovers, with Hodge and Melvin each committing six. It was the sixth time in seven games that North Carolina had forced 20 turnovers. "They do play good defense," Hodge said. "But our turnovers, many of them were unforced."
